Blog.post: Q. What is artificial intelligence? A. It is the science and engineering of making intelligent machines, especially intelligent computer programs. It is related to the similar task of using computers to understand human intelligence, but AI does not have to confine itself to methods that are biologically observable. Q. Yes, but what is intelligence? A. Intelligence is the computational part of the ability to achieve goals in the world. Varying kinds and degrees of intelligence occur in people, many animals and some machines.

Tensor algebra mainly, with a little topology and higher calculus, if need be. But with feeling, in the cybernetic spirit.": Come, let us hasten to a higher plane, Where dyads tread the fairy fields of Venn, Their indices bedecked from one to n, Commingled in an endless Markov chain! Come, every frustum longs to be a cone, And every vector dreams of matrices. Hark to the gentle gradient of the breeze: It whispers of a more ergodic zone. In perusing through archives that I've stored at my parents' abode, I flippped upon one of my proposals for a physical book. The project entailed the concept of how the universe began with chaos, and as it slowly evolved, order came about. Humans attempt to further order the universe by creating and using technology (though it is typically understood as a means to facilitate survival). This book was going to pictorially illustrate data structures progressing from chaos to order. Though the end result is not worth anyone's attention with the exception of a personal psychologist, this project has some interesting ties to my current interest in artificial Darwinism / evolutionary computing, and picks up on that initial spark of interest that I had some four years ago. As a sidenote - I'm awaiting the postal arrival of The Blind Watchmaker by Richard Dawkins. A review of the work from amazon.com : The title of this 1986 work, Dawkins's second book, refers to the Rev. William Paley's 1802 work, Natural Theology, which argued that just as finding a watch would lead you to conclude that a watchmaker must exist, the complexity of living organisms proves that a Creator exists. Not so, says Dawkins: "All appearances to the contrary, the only watchmaker in nature is the blind forces of physics, albeit deployed in a very special way... it is the blind watchmaker." Dawkins is a hard-core scientist: he doesn't just tell you what is so, he shows you how to find out for yourself. For this book, he wrote Biomorph, one of the first artificial life programs. You can check Dawkins's results on your own Mac or PC

Today at www.genobyte.com I discovered an intriguing idea which is a radical new approach to traditional circuit design called evolvable hardware. Usually if there is a change in a complex circuit it needs to be redesigned, but designers are now working on hardware that reconfigures itself; "this process is guided by a genetic algorithm which operates on a population of circuit chromosomes (bitstreams defining the logical functions and wiring of the circuit)". It's pretty amazing: a population of competing circuits are run over generations, and each new generation inherits the characteristics of the fitter parents via mutation and recombination of chromosomes. Evolvable hardware can be adaptive at different levels as well (changing requirements, environment, hardware failure, etc). [microphotograph of a human chromosome enlarged 30,000 times ]

Now here are some thoughts that I was having while walking to the KU from West 4th Street: it seems rather easy for other organisms and animals to make a living: swimming, running, flying. Why does it seem like it has to be so difficult for humans? Why do we put ourselves under so much stress? A better solution to survival than making money and spending it when going out seems to be to take whenever possible. If there is a drink on the bar, why not take a sip? If there are pastries out in a dish in a restaurant, why not take? Why even wait around to pay off the bill? I have no qualms about this, as my scope is life-long rather than temporal and situational. Over the long run of things, this sort of behavior would lead to a life less burdened by conventional troubles and complaints, and would lead to a greater level of comfort within the city.

warning: this is a rant in response to the attitude taken by many artists that mathematics is something beyond their means, a playground solely for mathematicians. or that programming, too, is outside of their scope. perhaps i was once in this category, but i've been discovering that nature is essentially programmatic. the way that dna functions to copy information to propagate the species can be broken down into a sequence of steps. we exist in the midst of sequences: seasons, planetary phases, the life cycle of humans from childhood through puberty to adulthood, and so on. to avoid the underlying mathematics of our daily existence and to leave it up to intuition and gut feeling is to completely sidestep what it means to live in this century. we are machines, and the machines that we create mimic computational capabilities found in basic elements of life. the more sophisticated our algorithms get will mean that we are better able to understand the world we live in.

urlLink since strange attractors have recently been an ill-defined subject of conversation, i ought to elaborate with a proper definition and description. it stems from chaos theory, in which there is an attempt to find the underlying order in apparently random data. within a bounded system there are long-term patterns which aren't simple periodic oscillations or orbits. they can be like lopsided spirals, and these same patterns can emerge even with different initial conditions. yesterday, out of desperation for inspiration, i watched "the butterfly effect". in it the main character experiences a number of parallel realities in which things always seem to go to hell regardless of how he attempts to rectify the initial conditions. finally, he has to completely alter how his life unfolds: he eradicates any possible early experiences with the woman that he loves by frightening her away when they first meet. it seems that first impressions do hold a lot of weight.

urlLink today i played galaga (on an urlLink emulator ; my preference is urlLink macmame ). today was different. i watched shots fire directly into my fighter ship (a location currently updated with each passing nanosecond). i avoided hits. i learned of my enemy's behavior. the enemy ships (or bugs) never venture into furthermost right or left areas of the screen... (and according to some hackers, if you avoid the two ships on the left-hand side for the first or second screen and avoid their hits for 15 minutes, then you can get through the whole game without having ships fire at you). my ploy to avoid hits was empowering. by observing my enemy's moves and conserving my own energy, i was learning about my enemy's behavior and was thus able to make predictions about it and "dance" around the screen. this is somewhat like kung fu (or maybe capoeira), in that you redirect energy (and may learn of your opponent's tactics) in order to defeat him/her with accuracy. it's a delicate balance between giving and taking, coming and going, all life is flowing... today i attempted to create a basic genetic algorithm in proce55ing (which i may be able to finish tomorrow; the survival factor within a population of circles is dependent upon how dark they are, and they all begin with various shades from white to black). three things need to happen: selection, mutation and reproduction. the procedures for evolving a generation thus must be: 1. evaluate fitness of all individuals in the population 2. create a new pop. by performing genetic operators on it 3. discard old pop. and use the new pop. this cycle is clearly explained at urlLink hitchhiker's guide to evolutionary computation (thank you, douglass adams, you have done good in this world). the mechanisms at work here are no mystery, but i have a number of questions that need to be answered: 1. how will evolution be used as a key element in the design & implementation of the project? 2. what is the environment, exactly? 3. how will individual structures perform (what's going on)? 4. how is the fitness of the individual determined?

lately i have been bothered by the way people undermine others. sometimes it is indiscernible, and other times blatantly obvious, especially when dealing with the...unillumined ones. i think that it stems from our inability to truly comprehend the amount of brilliance that can be found within each individual. it is easier for us to perceive things at a distance as homogenous, and allows us to go about living within a carefully controlled environment where predictability reigns supreme. when you meet someone for the first time, there is the initial assumption that you are nothing, nobody, and have done nothing in your life. the first few words then define where you are from by your dialect, and it's associations begin to form in the other person's mind. by the time you get to exchange information about each other's occupation, it's all over. you are now a living example of someone's archetype. it's a pity that assumers don't extend themselves beyond their own ego to learn from others around them and to give others the benefit of a doubt. it seems that the only way that this can really be accomplished is when the assumer gets involved in an intimate relationship with someone else; then the awe, inspiration, beauty and knowledge pour forth from one individual to another, and for the sake of love, the assumer's mind is wide open. butter put up a link to a site called urlLink found photos which does a p2p search for photos and puts them up in this compiled form, and pulls the veil off of our assumptions immediately. if there is a photo that i want anyone to find, it's this one of jon:

i'm having difficulty these days remembering information that i once acquired in the past. in order to retain such information, i've decided to make little stories for myself. there were once two little circuits named sparky and buzzer. sparky was wont to spark when she found an energy source, and buzzer tended to, well, buzz with sufficient energy. they couldn't do anything on their own, but together, they enjoyed many an occasion of frightening hospital patients into thinking that they inadvertently caused the onset of the third world war, when in reality they had merely buzzed their nurse. now, the catalyst for their action was a friendly little clock signal named richard. richard coordinated the actions of sparky and buzzer by oscillating between a high and low state. sparky and buzzer were in a pipelined digital circuit, and when data was in sparky's domain, sparky would get sort of happy, but never be completely happy. after that stage was processed, sparky would hand it off to richard, who would then tick and latch the intermediate results into registers in buzzer's domain. but since the sparky and buzzer would have their thrill for five minutes, there was data continually entering into sparky, then buzzer, repeat, and so on. ... to be continued oh, and do feel free to point out technical inconsistencies if you notice some flawed logic...
